thread.title: Malcolm Turnbull unfazed by Kiwi anger during first foray on world stage
thread.title_full: Malcolm Turnbull unfazed by Kiwi anger during first foray on world stage

title: Malcolm Turnbull unfazed by Kiwi anger during first foray on world stage
text:
COMMENT

Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Malcolm Turnbull receives Maori welcome Malcolm Turnbull receives a 'Powhiri' welcoming ceremony during his first overseas trip as prime minister.
PT0M41S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings The Maori warrior approaches Malcolm Turnbull slowly, deliberately, wielding a spear-like weapon known as a taiaha. He drops a token at the Prime Minister's feet before retreating a few paces.
This is the powhiri, a Maori welcome that begins with this, a challenge: are you friend or foe? Turnbull retrieves the token and so the warrior knows the answer: friend.
The warrior strikes his own right thigh, indicating to his tribe that Turnbull comes in peace and should be granted access to their marae, or meeting place: in this case, Government House in Auckland.
Malcolm Turnbull is welcomed in an official ceremony by a Maori warrior at Government House in Auckland. Photo: Hannah Peters
Just as well, too. Because as Turnbull and his New Zealand counterpart John Key are at pains to make clear when they talk to the media a little while later, Australia and New Zealand are in fact more than just friends: they're family, and nothing will ever stand between them.
Advertisement There will be disagreements, sure. For example, New Zealand hasn't exactly welcomed Australia's new enthusiasm for detaining and deporting its citizens, even if they have lived in Australia most of their lives and have only committed minor crimes.
But families argue, right?
The disagreement certainly didn't faze our new Prime Minister. By giving Key a small concession – a fast-tracked appeal process – he did what all good diplomats seek to do: let the other country save face while surrendering nothing of value.
Turnbull didn't exactly set himself a big test when he chose New Zealand to be his first overseas destination as PM.
It's a safe, friendly nation where the praise is plentiful and the controversies easily contained. Nonetheless, it was a confident and assured performance from a man who looks as comfortable on the world stage as he does on the domestic – even when warriors are coming at him with spears.
